frames.verbose-text: Through promoting Met-Integrin association , HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes coordinated and enhanced endothelial cell migration through activation of the PI-3 kinase pathway involving a Ras dependent mechanism whereas a Ras independent and attenuated migratory response was promoted by co-stimulation of cells with HGF and a non binding partner ECM glycoprotein such as collagen-1 .

Through promoting Met-Integrin association , HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes coordinated and enhanced endothelial cell migration through activation of the PI-3 kinase pathway involving a Ras dependent mechanism whereas a Ras independent and attenuated migratory response was promoted by co-stimulation of cells with HGF and a non binding partner ECM glycoprotein such as collagen-1 .

We also presented evidence that the VEGF and VEGFR -2 pathway is coupled to the integrin alpha5beta1 through a mechanism involving the promotion of an integrin alpha5beta1-VEGFR-2 signalling moiety generated as a consequence of receptor ligation by a VEGF and FN complex .
More recently , we presented data demonstrating that FN significantly enhanced VEGF mediated migration of CD34+ cells and their differentiation into endothelial cells     .

frames.text: FN significantly enhanced VEGF-mediated migration of CD34+
frames.verbose-text: More recently , we presented data demonstrating that FN significantly enhanced VEGF mediated migration of CD34+ cells and their differentiation into endothelial cells     .

frames.text: HGF induces the expression of VEGF
frames.verbose-text: HGF , also termed scatter factor , has a well established role in tumourogenesis but may be an important mediator of neovascularization since studies show that HGF induces the expression of VEGF in endothelial cells in vitro and that HGF synergises with VEGF to promote capillary-tube assembly in collagen matrices        .

Endothelial cells pre-treated with FPT-III displayed a profound reduction in cell migration of 50 % and 73 % when stimulated with HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes respectively compared to cells pre-treated with GGTI ( Fig .

frames.text: GTP-loaded Ras after endothelial cells were stimulated with HGF in the presence and absence of ECM molecules (Fig.    &   . Endothelial cells stimulated with HGF alone showed high levels of GTP-Ras at 60 min post-stimulation and this was sustained even at 120 min (Fig.    . In contrast, cells co-stimulated with HGF and collagen-1 showed activation of Ras at 60 min post-stimulation but to a significantly lower degree (approx 50% compared to HGF alone Fig.    , with the signal diminished by 120 min. With HGF-FN and HGF-VN co-stimulation, GTP-Ras levels were more than two-fold higher than observed when cells were co-stimulated with HGF-collagen-1 (Fig.    . Significantly, GTP-Ras levels were sustained at 120 min consistent with the observations of the activation profiles for the MAP kinase and PI-3 kinase pathways. These studies suggested that inhibiting Ras in cells stimulated with HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes would exhibit reduced migration responses. To test this hypothesis, cells were treated with the membrane permeable farnesyltransferase inhibitor FPT-III, which inhibits Ras function as a consequence of the loss of membrane localization in the absence of farnesylation. Upon stimulation with HGF-FN, endothelial cells treated with FPT-III (100 muM) showed little activation of Ras following HGF-FN stimulation compared to basal levels in unstimulated cells (Fig.    . In comparison, pre-treatment of cells with the geranylgeranyl transferase inhibitor GGTI (2 muM) had little inhibitory effect on HGF-FN induced Ras

frames.text: Ras activation reduces the activation of PI-3

frames.text: Panel A-HGF in the absence of ECM molecules can activate the Map

frames.text: PI-3 kinase (AKT phosphorylation) and Erk 1/2 phosphorylation
frames.verbose-text: The enhanced responses of HMVEC to HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes is consistent with the observation that in these cells the activity of Ras , PI-3 kinase ( AKT phosphorylation ) and Erk 1 and 2 phosphorylation were sustained , and in the case of Ras and Akt , were 2-3 fold higher than observed in cells stimulated with HGF and collagen-1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  .

The enhanced responses of HMVEC to HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes is consistent with the observation that in these cells the activity of Ras , PI-3 kinase ( AKT phosphorylation ) and Erk 1 and 2 phosphorylation were sustained , and in the case of Ras and Akt , were 2-3 fold higher than observed in cells stimulated with HGF and collagen-1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  .

Therefore , our data and model demonstrating the sustained activation of Ras and PI-3 kinase by stimulation of endothelial cells with HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes is consistent with previous work showing Ras to be a key regulator of PI-3 kinase .

The enhanced responses of HMVEC to HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes is consistent with the observation that in these cells the activity of Ras , PI-3 kinase ( AKT phosphorylation ) and Erk 1 and 2 phosphorylation were sustained , and in the case of Ras and Akt , were 2-3 fold higher than observed in cells stimulated with HGF and collagen-1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  .

frames.text: Ras in this system appears important for the sustained and enhanced activation of the PI-3
frames.verbose-text: Although the precise nature of the interaction between the Met tyrosine kinase and integrins was not elucidated , the role of Ras in this system appears important for the sustained and enhanced activation of the PI-3 kinase and Erk kinase pathways .

frames.text: Ras in this system appears important for the sustained and enhanced activation of the PI-3 kinase and Erk
frames.verbose-text: Although the precise nature of the interaction between the Met tyrosine kinase and integrins was not elucidated , the role of Ras in this system appears important for the sustained and enhanced activation of the PI-3 kinase and Erk kinase pathways .

The identification of a Ras dependent pathway in endothelial cells specifically activated with HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes as opposed to HGF in the presence of collagen-1 is significant and correlates with Met-integrin association .

frames.text: HGF in combination with FN prolongs the survival of GM-colony-forming cells      and enhanced the adhesion and motility of MTLn3
frames.verbose-text: Furthermore , it was recently demonstrated that HGF in combination with FN prolongs the survival of GM-colony-forming cells      and enhanced the adhesion and motility of MTLn3 breast carcinoma cells     .

frames.text: HGF-FN and HGF-VN molecular complexes induce the formation of Met-integrin
frames.verbose-text: Similarly , the present work has shown that HGF-FN and HGF-VN molecular complexes induce the formation of Met-integrin signalling complexes promoting the transduction of a unique Ras dependent signal .

frames.text: HGF-VN molecular complexes induce the formation of Met-integrin
frames.verbose-text: Similarly , the present work has shown that HGF-FN and HGF-VN molecular complexes induce the formation of Met-integrin signalling complexes promoting the transduction of a unique Ras dependent signal .

frames.text: Gab-1, which directly interacts with the p85
frames.verbose-text: This observation is intriguing bearing in mind that Met has been shown to activate PI-3 kinase in epithelial cells via recruitment and activation of Gab-1 , which directly interacts with the p85 subunit     .

In contrast , our studies using primary endothelial cells showed that integrin ligation was essential for generating a significant migratory signal via PI-3 kinase and in the case of HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes , for promoting the association of Met with the integrins alpha5beta1 and alphavbeta3 respectively .

In contrast to the migratory signals promoted by VEGF-FN molecular complexes    , HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes induce a response in endothelial cells characterized by a tight coupling of the PI-3 kinase pathway to cell migration .

frames.text: Met receptor is unable to activate PI-3
frames.verbose-text: However , the lack of a significant migratory response , coupled with the absence of Akt phosphorylation observed in the present study , suggests that in primary endothelial cells the Met receptor is unable to activate PI-3 kinase without cooperative signals from the ECM and integrins .

However , the lack of a significant migratory response , coupled with the absence of Akt phosphorylation observed in the present study , suggests that in primary endothelial cells the Met receptor is unable to activate PI-3 kinase without cooperative signals from the ECM and integrins .

Indeed , Met association with the integrins alpha5beta1 and alphavbeta3 was dependent upon the activation of both Met and integrins through ligation of their cognate ligands since tyrosine phosphorylation of Met by HGF alone could not induce integrin association ( Fig .

In support of this contention , HGF-FN and HGF-VN complexes were identified in the supernatants derived from degranulated platelet suspensions indicating that these complexes do exist in vivo and may be deposited at sites of vessel perturbation or injury .
Furthermore , HGF positively regulates VEGF expression and down regulates TSP-1 , an inhibitor of angiogenesis , thereby promoting angiogenesis     .
